case_prompt: A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of left leg pain for three months.
further_information: The pain is characterized by a continuous creamping in the left calf that starts after walking two blocks and goes away with rest.
The patient has a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus.
Family history includes a pulmonary embolism experienced by his mother at age 55.
The patient quit smoking 5 years ago.
The patient's temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, and left arm blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. Left ankle blood pressure is 210/150.
Physical exam shows symmetric legs without swelling, redness, or skin breakdown.
